title: MPs take aim at City ministers' refusal to close rogue investment loophole
text:
The Government has rejected proposals to strengthen the City watchdog to help its fight against rogue investment schemes – which have cost consumers thousands of pounds.

The Treasury Committee, an influential group of MPs, had called for a formal system to be established so the regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), could ask for additional powers when it saw gaps in its framework.

However, the Government has rejected any changes to the current system. It argued ministers and Parliament should judge what powers the FCA needs, and not the watchdog itself.

The government's decision is a blow to those inside the FCA who had hoped for greater authority to clamp down on rogue investments....
